I don't ever intend to get married. Whenever I express this to somebody they respond like that is a decision that requires some justification. Neither my girlfriend or I are religious people, nor do we like parties, so holy matrimony and a wedding are out. If I were to get a legal marriage I would just be having the government affirm my relationship, what do I care about what the government thinks of my relationship? Admittedly Marriage is a tradition in both of our families, but that doesn't really mean much to me. So I don't see that there is any justification for my getting married.
 
 Furthermore, though I don't need to in order to justify not getting married, I can think of justification for avoiding marriage. I think its inauthentic, peoples feelings and emotions change all the time, how can a person really promise to always feel a particular way? Also, I've heard multiple accounts of people feeling trapped by marriage. I knew a guy, John, who felt the same way I do about marriage, but he discovered that he would receive some benefits at work if he was married to his girlfriend, so he did. He says that ever since their relationship hasn't been the same because he Is never as sure of his love. He says that before they were married he took for granted that her staying with him and his staying with her, was justified only by love, but after the marriage, he could never be sure if he was with her because he really loved her, or because it would be difficult to leave her or if she felt the same way.
 
 is there any good reason to face the negitive possiblitys and get married?

is there any good reason to face the negitive possiblitys and get married?

 
 Legal marriage is accepted by general society as a financial and moral commitment statement between two people. Depending on your lifestyle and personal wealth, lack of same could close social and financial doors. It remains a personal decision within society not devoted to rituals and/or power.

 There are a few benefits for being married. In our scoiety it is not so much of a religious insitutition as a economic one. 1) there are tax benefits (assuming you are in the states). 2) A spouce has rights for authorising medical treatment in case of a medical emergancy where the other partner is not able to respond for some reason. 3) the inheritance
 law are a lto simpler. If your partner dies without a will, didyou know their heirs in come into your apartment, and take half of anything they want, unless you have evidence it si yours alone? 4) if there should be offspring, there is protection provided by the law for the wellbeing of those kids. You, as their father (you hope at least), have more rights for them (and more obligations of course).
